title: Why the first all-electric Porsche is not an SUV
text:
Tony Davis Motoring Writer Oct 11, 2019 — 12.00am Share

Why is the first fully electric Porsche, the Taycan, a sedan? The SUV segment is much healthier, so why not make one of those? That’s a line of questioning that Dr Stefan Weckbach is more than familiar with.

“[This] is a big investment,” reasons Weckbach, vice-president, Taycan product line. “We need to have an offer with which we can realise significant volumes – therefore we decided to go in a segment we haven’t been in before.

The car offers "typical Porsche performance", says Weckbach.

“We already have two successful SUVs in the market and we didn’t want to substitute ourselves in the SUV segment. In the D sedan segment we have the Panamera.”

That’s why the Taycan is aimed at the smaller “C sedan segment”, where Weckbach believes Porsche can gain new customers. Initial signs are very positive. In the past 18 months, more than 25,000 people have paid deposits of €2500 (about $4079) or equivalent to gain a spot in the queue – and half those have never owned a Porsche before.

We concentrated on our own targets for the Taycan to be a true Porsche. — Stefan Weckbach, VP, Taycan product line

If these people turn into buyers (strictly speaking, the deposits are refundable), the first year’s planned production is more than accounted for. Fortunately, says Weckbach, there is some flexibility to up the numbers.

The Taycan will not be the sole electric Porsche for long. A high-riding Cross Turismo sibling will go into production by the end of next year, says Weckbach, and there are “maybe some additional ideas for future models” based on the Taycan. There will also be a fully electric Macan SUV as soon as next year.

Weckbach is an admirer of Tesla, and will not be drawn into any comparisons. “We concentrated on our own targets … for the Taycan to be a true Porsche and as close as possible to our icon, the 911.”

The Taycan meets all the brand’s standards on performance, charging speed, range, design quality and handling, he says. It offers “the typical Porsche performance on acceleration, on repeatability of power, constant level of power, on braking power and we are not going to comment on competitors…. we are offering a Porsche with the expectations our customers have.”
description: The Taycan is radical in more ways than one – join the queue if you’re intrigued.
